text: The Tribe of the Wolf is a band of warriors and hunters drawn by one man: Huern the Wolf, the “Black Wolf.” Many, though not all, of the tribesmen are Skin Wolves or Werekin, united in kinship and spirit as one pack. For now, the Tribe hunts over the tundras and mountains of the Naglfari Plain, but Huern and his pack may yet venture to more distant lands in search of greater quarry.

Huern has come to be called many names: “the Black Wolf,” “the Wolf Chieftain,” and even “Olricsson.” Yet Huern’s life had more humble origins — the son of a dying thrall, his youth was a constant struggle to prove himself. Proven he has become, for now Huern’s charisma and skill in battle have drawn together a tribe of Skin Wolves and Werekin from across the north, eager to accompany him throughout the world on hunts, on raids, and in conquest.

Alfkael the Bloodfather is a local legend among the Norscan tribes. A wanderer belonging to the old tradition of the healers and diviners known as Vitki. “Old One-Eye” is as comfortable amidst the ice and snow of the northern mountains as he is by a great hall’s hearth, and to be visited by Alfkael is a portent of luck and fortune for a Norscan village. Alfkael is slow to anger, but when he does, he brings the wild fury of the North and its Winds with him into battle.

Formerly known as Vivienne d’Arden, Asta is the daughter of a Bretonnian forester hanged for false allegations of poaching. Asta met Huern after the Wolf Chieftain was gravely injured during a raid, nursing him back to health deep in the forest. When Huern returned to Norsca, Asta accompanied him, taking a new, Norscan name. Years later, Asta has married Huern and become chieftess of the Tribe of the Wolf, delighting in the wild north and hunting across its icy lands.

When Asta first arrived in Norsca, she marveled at the beauty of the frozen peaks and the frigid sea. Greatest among the wonders she encountered was Gjálfr, an ice wolf of incomparable size. Now, woman and wolf are inseparable companions, venturing together into the wilds in search of worthy prey.

Once a bondsman in service to an Aesling jarl, Uldsdau was a giant among his tribesmen—a berserker of such stature that some thought him to be a troll. Yet once Uldsdau was blessed with the power of the werekin, he thought he could no longer serve any master. Years after slaying his jarl and stalking the tundra in search of foes to slay, Uldsdau was proven wrong. Huern Olricsson, besting Uldsdau in a duel and sparing his life, welcomed the berserker into his tribe. Uldsdau has been Huern’s sworn blood-brother ever since.

“Yes, my mother was a thrall. What of it? I have torn chieftains, champions, and monsters asunder with my claws. Origins hold no meaning to wolves; only strength, cunning, and authority have value. Tell me, coward, would you like to test mine?” \\n\\n- Huern Olricsson

“Greetings, World Walker. I hear that you’ve just returned from slaying yet another champion — tell me, where did you voyage this time? Ulthuan? Cathay? Truly, no other among our people can claim to have seen as many lands as you. But I tell you now, it will not always be so — for ever has my blood been stirred by the thrill of the hunt, and that thrill is never sated.”\\n\\n- Huern Olricsson, to Wulfrik the Wanderer

The Packlords are the greatest of the Werekin, champions among the wolves of Norsca. Bound by a primal pack hunter’s instinct, they follow the strongest among their number and are in turn followed by lesser Skin Wolves. For many years, Huern has stood atop the hierarchy, but it is a common thing for ambitious Packlords to challenge each other for dominance.
“The choice is yours: bare your neck or bare your steel. It makes little difference. Either way, I will carve you apart with my axes and feast upon your corpse.”\\n\\n- Uldsdau

“The only love I have for Bretonnia is its lands — the shade of its forests and the warmth of its pastures. As for its folk...at best, they are cowards willfully bent in servitude to undeserving masters. At worst, they are robbers dressed in silk, who pretend that their dishonourable acts are chivalrous.”\\n\\n- Asta of the Wood, formerly called Vivienne d’Arden

“I am Alfkael, and I am the Cloaked One. I am Battle-Wolf, Forni Song-Weaver. I have as many names as there are bodies on a battlefield, as many stories as there are hairs in a dwarf’s beard. I have gained wisdom upon the peaks overlooking the Sea of Chaos, seen the Eagle’s whispers in the lights dancing in the winter sky. The winds are my skalds, the beasts my companions.”\\n\\n- Alfkael the Bloodfather
